{{About|the shield}} {{Distinguish|Apsis}} [[File:Hoplitodromos Staatliche Antikensammlungen 1471.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Hoplitodromos]] with aspis and full body [[armour]] depicted in a Greek vase dated to 550 BC.]] An '''aspis''' ({{lang-grc|[[wikt:ἀσπίς|ἀσπίς]]}}, plural ''aspides'', {{lang|grc|ἀσπίδες}}), sometimes also referred to as a '''hoplon''', was the heavy wooden [[shield]] used by the infantry in various periods of [[ancient Greece]]. <ref name="Jr.2011">{{cite book|author=Fred Eugene Ray, Jr.|quote=The word ''hoplon'' sometimes denoted this piece of equipment, but that word found use most often in the plural (''hopla'') to describe all the tools of war (i.e., arms, with ''[[hoplite]]s'' signifying a man at arms).|title=Land Battles in 5th Century BC Greece: A History and Analysis of 173 Engagements|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NECnIjWtIMEC&pg=PA9|date=11 August 2011|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-5260-6|page=9}}</ref>
==Construction== An aspis was deeply dished and made primarily of wood. Some had a thin sheet of [[bronze]] on the outer face, often just around the rim. In some periods, the convention was to decorate the shield; in others, it was usually left plain. Probably the most famous aspis decoration is that of [[Sparta]] (Lacedaemon): a capital [[lambda]] ({{lang|grc|Λ}}), for ''Lacedaemon''{{Citation needed|date=August 2016}} ({{lang|grc|[[wikt:Λακεδαίμων|Λακεδαίμων]]}}). From the late 5th century BCE, [[Athens|Athenian]] [[hoplite]]s commonly used the [[little owl]], while the shields of [[Thebes, Greece|Theban]] hoplites were sometimes decorated with a [[Sphinx#Greek traditions|sphinx]], or the club of [[Heracles]].
The aspis measured at least {{convert|0.91|m}} in diameter and weighed about {{convert|7.3|kg}}, and it was about {{convert|25|-|38|mm}} thick.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zimmel, Girard|first=Jonathan, Todd|title=Hoplites Arms and Armor|url=http://faculty.fairfield.edu/rosivach/cl115/military/hoplites.htm|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref> This large shield was made possible partly by its shape, which allowed it to be supported on the shoulder. The revolutionary part of the shield was, in fact, the grip. Known as an {{linktext|Argive}} grip, it placed the handle at the edge of the shield, and was supported by a leather fastening (for the forearm) at the centre. This allowed hoplites more mobility with the shield, as well as the ability to capitalize on their offensive capabilities and better support the [[phalanx]]. The shield rested on a man's shoulders, stretching down the knees. These large shields were designed for a mass of hoplites to push forward into the opposing army, a move called ''[[othismos]]'', and it was their most essential equipment.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sage|first=Michael M|title=Warfare in Ancient Greece: A Sourcebook|year=1996|publisher=Routledge|location=London, GBR|pages=281}}</ref> That the shield was also made of wood<ref name="Grotowski2010">{{cite book|author=Piotr Grotowski|title=Arms and Armour of the Warrior Saints: Tradition and Innovation in Byzantine Iconography (843–1261)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k2spzj0jNVsC&pg=PA215|date=24 September 2010|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-18548-8|page=215}}</ref> made it possible for warriors to use it as a [[floatation device]] for crossing rivers, and its large, round shape allowed it to be used for hauling the bodies of the dead from the battlefield.{{Citation Needed|date=March 2015}}
Such shields did not tend to survive the passage of time very well, and only one aspis has survived into modernity with sufficient preservation to allow us to determine the details of its construction: this shield is called the "[[Bomarzo]]" or "Vatican" shield, and it is currently located in the [[Vatican city|Vatican]], within the [[Museo Gregoriano Etrusco]]. It was discovered in 1830 near Bomarzo in [[Lazio]], central Italy.<ref name="Travis2014">{{cite book|author=John and Hilary Travis|title=Roman Shields|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=--EOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA33|date=3 July 2014|publisher=Amberley Publishing Limited|isbn=978-1-4456-3843-0|page=33}}</ref>
